I haven't yet played the Blu Ray or dvd but the digital copy is a subscription to a service owned by Disney which you must subscribe to, and agree to having your personal information shared with Disney companies.  The redeem function sent with your disk does not work and you are forced to call Disney for access to its website and redemption codes. This is not a copy on a digital medium.  After going through all the gyrations to get a digital stream, it is of substandard quality in both picture and audio.  It's hard to believe this is a "restored" film.  My old cuz copy sounds and looks better.  I wouldn't waste my money on this and it is likely being returned for a much less expensive version.

Mary Poppins is to movies what Brian Wilson's "Pet Sounds" was to music. After the wildly successful "Flubber" films that utilized the "red screen" process, Walt sought to do what his contemporaries had yet to achieve: the seamless marriage of live action an animation on film.  The sheer "star power" (A phrase that had not even been imagined in 1964.) of Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke gave the Disney studio a degree of latitude that would allow them to take risks that with lesser stars would have been impossible. While the overall effect of the live action over animation is primitive by today's standards, the audiences of 1964 ate it up. An although the storyline of the film was kind of anemic, the sheer power and screen presence of Julie and Dick made the implausible seem possible. Walt scored another home run. Another institution was cemented into our popular culture. And most importantly, another love affair was created for a mythical, magical, nanny in the person of Julie Andrews. Four Academy awards later, Best Actress, Best Score, Best Visual Effects, and Best Editing; we have a benchmark to which so many artists from so many disciplines aspired to meet.

Our family loves this old jewel. I would focus on the digital part of this blu-ray purchase since the description does not state clearly. This blu-ray comes with blu-ray (of course), dvd, and the digital movie code. This code can be redeemed on Disney's movies anywhere then it would immediately show up on iTunes or Vudu or whatever service you linked with Disney movies anywhere service. As of today the digital movie code included in the package works fine.

Julie Andrews does a marvelous job in her role as Mary Poppins to help this family come together.  She enters the home at a time of turmoil when both parents do not know how to parent their children and the children misbehave due to lack of instruction.  Jane and Michael, the children, misbehave to gain their parents' attention but their parents' see their behavior as a reason to hire a new nanny.  Mary Poppins steps in and first teaches the children so they do not misbehave and then "teaches" the parents "how to be parents".  She accomplishes this by teaching the children to clean their room and by having fun in the park, the chalk pavement picture.  These activities help the children learn responsibility and how to have fun in a constructive manner.  Throughout the movie, Mr. Banks, the father, is angered more and more with each new story his kids have to tell him about their day with Mary Poppins.  Upon taking his kids to work with him one day, the movie depicts that he does not know how to parent his kids and, after losing his job later that night, realizes he should be a better father.  Due to Mary Poppins's presence in the house, both parents learn to support their children more and provide them with emotional needs as well as functional needs in a family.

The movie holds up well as a glorious musical.  The acting, singing, choreography, staging, special effects are all great.  The plot still works.  This is a movie my wife and I love watching over and over.  The blu ray version is beautiful.  The quality of the image shows itself during the extreme close-ups of Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke -- the images are crystal clear with no blurring on a high quality 53 inch LCD HDTV.  The sound is excellent.  The DVD authoring is a little idiosyncratic.  Though "resume play" is activated but is only present after a lengthy video introduction and it is hard to bypass the "previews."  There is a paucity of extras.

A little disappointed by the audio. I understand older films have limited technical leeway when it comes to remastering, but the sound is rather flat with little use of the rear speakers. The picture isn't much better than the old DVD I had. The only reason to splurge on this release is the compatibility with current technology- Blu-ray adds some preference controls and you can choose aspect ratio (unlike the DVD releases). The DVD locked down the aspect ratio for 4X3 screens, leaving too much black framing on ALL FOUR sides of image on wide screen LCD with no options to change that. "Zooming in" via TV controls created a fuzzy mess. The Blu-ray has all the bells and whistles you'd expect. Still love the film, though.

A classic for children and adults too. As enjoyable as ever. One thing worth mentioning: The set design is brilliant. The film was not actually shot in London but rather used painted backdrops and sets to recreate Edwardian London. The effect, in my opinion, is stunning. It doesn't look exactly like the city but an impressionistic image of the citythe city of one's imagination, as it were. It's feathered into the plot and themes of the movie so well that it acts as almost another character.

One of the great films of the 1960s and probably the summit of Walt Disney's filmmaking ventures, an immortal classic that matches the greatness of his early triumphs ("Snow White..', Pinocchio', 'Fantasia') and the great successor to The Wizard of Oz' in the genre of family/fantasy entertainment. Julie Andrews, an unknown quantity in producer Jack L .Warner's eyes when he opted to cast Audrey Hepburn over Andrews in the soon to be filmed movie version of 'My Fair Lady' (Andrews starred in the original Broadway production) became an overnight sensation for her brilliant portrayal of the british nanny with magical powers who is hired to care for the two children of The Banks family in Edwardian London.
Andrews ended up winning the Best Actress Oscar for 1964 and 'Marry Poppins' won 4 other Oscars including best score and song. The film still holds up beautifully over a half a century later. The Blu-ray edition is superb in image and sound. Highly recommended.

I have to admit this film was as lousy as it was when I first saw it as a girl. I love Julie Andrews in other roles, but this stick-up-her-butt nanny is too unlikable--and I usually enjoy unlikable characters as long as they're interesting. I think it's Poppins'  total lack of charm that keeps me from enjoying her. Also, the "who's going to mind the kids?" dilemma that never addresses the fact the actual mother (who, of course, isn't allowed to be the family breadwinner) could be the one to perform mothering only tells me I know nothing about life in privileged classes. I'm amazed she bothered to deal with the pregnancies at all.

The main message of the film is that your mother and father are too busy for you and the person they entrust you to will make you depend on her right before she abandons you. And she'll give you a lot of rules, which you're supposed to relish, and perform magical stunts, to keep you from totally hating her and her rules. I can't see kids or adults liking this message.

I bought this for my grandchildren, and they love it.  It's the magical story of a nanny who arrives on the scene of a houseful of self-absorbed people, and turns them into a loving, caring family.  Julie Andrews is unbeatable as Mary Poppins, practically perfect in every way, and Dick van Dyke is masterful as Bert, the chimneysweep.  After a botched vocal cord surgery, Ms. Andrews no longer sings, so it seems important to have this film on hand as a reminder of her once-magnificent voice.  Also, it's not widely known that she does the whistling in "A Spoonful of Sugar!"  What a spectacular talent.

I love this movie and I wanted to watch it streaming. The 1964 classic is based on the books of P. L. Travers, with a few Disney liberties thrown in. Travers' nanny, Mary Poppins, is somewhat more harsh and unpleasant in the books than in the film version. However, it is obvious that she is hiding a heart of gold inside and that she truly does love the children she takes care. Two of the children did not make the transition from the book, but they are definitely not missed. Julie Andrews is able to bring out the many facets of Mary Poppins without compromising the character, and of course her voice is legendary. The Sherman Brothers whipped up some of their most memorable tunes including "Jolly Holiday," "Spoonful of Sugar," and "Let's Go Fly a Kite."

In a nutshell, the story is about a magical nanny who swoops in to take care of the Banks children, Jane & Michael, and also help their father realize what he is missing by ignoring them the way that he does. Along the way she treats the children to adventures with a street performer/chimney sweep, Bert (Dick Van Dyke) as well as her Uncle Albert (Ed Wynn) who loves to laugh. One of the most memorable and touching sequences is the "Feed the Birds" numbers, with veteran actress Jane Darwell making her final screen appearance. One of Walt Disney's favorite songs, it is sure to bring a tear to many eyes.

Mary Poppins is a timeless Disney classic movie for all ages. My wife and I recently watched this movie with two of our grandkids ages 9 and 10. Both children were absolutely captivated by the movie's colorful characters and memorable songs. The special effects were amazing considering that the movie was made in 1964. We were concerned that the kids might become bored watching a 2 hour and 20 minute movie, but our fears were completely unfounded. They both fell in love with the movie and so did we all over again. I highly recommend this movie for everyone.

On a whim, I decided my baby daughter (still too young to appreciate it more than flashy colors and bouncy or lullaby-like music) needed to see Mary Poppins. Especially after seeing Saving Mr Banks, as a new father the movie means much more to me than I ever thought it would.
There are some scenes that go on a little too long and I don't love all of the songs or scenes, but that's not uncommon with that era of filmmaking. Sometimes the big production piece took center stage, plot and pacing be damned!  What still baffles me though is Dick Van Dyke's cockney accent. I get cockney sounds silly, but his version of it is ridiculous. He's not a bad actor, classically trained even, and the rest of the movie has such great attention to detail, it confuses me they let that slide... Perhaps there was some sort of clever social commentary it was making that I'm too dense to get.
Whatever the case, great movie and great DVD.

I grew up reading the "Mary Poppins" books by PL Travers and was so dismayed when I saw the movie that I became a cynic before the age of 13. My expectations had been very high -- some of my favorite books ever, brought to the screen by the beloved movie maker of "Snow White," "Cinderella," "Sleeping Beauty," "101 Dalmations," "The 3 Lives of Thomasina," "The Parent Trap," ....  But the movie I saw resembled the books only tangentially.  Who was this pretty, sweet nanny? Who were the pleasant, precocious kids taking the place of the far more flawed and true to life Jane and Michael (and where were the twins?)?  What the heck was ailing Bert, the matchman who did sidewalk art?  A book of wonderful stories was cherry-picked and turned into a song and dance show, with way too much about the parents (Mrs. Banks, a suffragette? Mr. Banks, getting fired?).  No doubt it would be a fine movie if it didn't claim to be "Mary Poppins."  But my major disappointment and abiding sorrow about this movie is that forevermore, this will be the "real" "Mary Poppins," and children loving the movie will not find what they expect if they ever turn to the books.  That is a tragedy.

I recently saw the stage play Marry Poppins.  There were some obvious differences between the play and the movie:  Obviously the play lacked the animation scenes, and there was none of the wizardry as displayed in the movie, especially the dancing and rollicking  chimney sweeps.  Some scenes depicted in the movie were omitted in the play while one scene was enacted in the play which did not appear in the movie.  Overall, both productions of Mary Poppins I found equally satisfying and both are classics.

Now that "Saving Mr. Banks" has been released and the back story of this movie is known, it's an even greater masterpiece than it was!  This version (at least the one that came up automatically) is not the original screen size so some of the dance numbers have portions that cannot be seen due to the enlargement of the main center portion of the original movie. (The farther sides to the left and right are off the screen).  Still, it is by far one of the best movies ever made and this anniversary edition looks great.  It doesn't appear to have been restored at all and the original film grain shows up clearly in Blu-ray, perhaps because it is enlarged in the center of the screen.  The bonus features are a DELIGHT to see, especially for die-hard Disneyphiles like myself.  The interview with Richard Sherman, Julie Andrews and Dick VanDyke (what a treasure that they are all still with us!) is just wonderful.  And the actor who played Richard Sherman sits and talks with the real Richard Sherman...great piece and thoroughly enjoyable.  If you love Disney, don't miss this disc!

I recently read the original novel, and it was fascinating...

But I am impressed by the movie. I have no idea why Disney included the suffragist element in the movie, but I adore it, and have done even as a kid.

Having aged and gotten more sophisticated (arguably), I am impressed by the way the movie shows both Mary and Bert as being trickster characters. OK, mild and benevolent ones, but still! They channel the negative chaotic energy of the Banks's kids against their parents's formulaic propriety, leading to a more meaningful relationship for all.

Add in really catchy songs, and special effects that are rather dated but not awful even after 50 years- and this is a great movie, with more to think about than you remember from watching it as a kid.

Walt Disney's Mary Poppins (1964). Rated G. Running Time: 2 hours, 18 mins. Directed by Robert Stevenson. Produced by Walt Disney and Bill Walsh. Screenplay written by Bill Walsh and Don DaGradi. Story based upon the books of P.L. Travers. A nanny from a cloud in the England sky floats down by umbrella to the residence of the Banks family. The father (David Tomlinson) and the hired help, the cook Mrs. Brill (Reta Shaw) and the maid, Ellen (Hermione Baddeley) are in need of another nanny for the children, Michael (Matthew Garber) and Jane (Karen Dotrice), especially since the last nanny, Katie Nanna (Elsa Lanchester), quit after the children ran away from home again. So the children write a letter of the kind of nanny they would like to have, but the father wants a nanny that is more stern and firm. He rips up the letter and places it in the fireplace. Magically, the pieces of the letter from the children, go up the chimney and fly up to the sky. And so the nanny, Mary Poppins (Julie Andrews), arrives to help the children in her magical way. Also in the cast: Dick Van Dyke, Glynis Johns, Arthur Treacher, Reginald Owen, Ed Wynn, Jane Darwell, Arthur Malet, Alan Napier, J. Pat O'Malley. Paul Frees is the voice of the Barnyard horse. Thurl Ravenscoft is the voice of the hog and does Andrew's whisper. Julie Andrews was 27 years of age at time of filming. Dick Van Dyke was 37 years of age at time of filming. Karen Dotice was 7 years of age at time of filming. Matthew Garber was 7 years of age at the time of filming. He passed away June 13, 1977 from pancreatitis at the age of 21. Option of language: English Dolby Digital, French, Spanish. original Theatrical Stereo Mix. Option of Subtitles: English, French, Spanish. Bonus Features: Disney's Song Selection, Backstage Disney, Audio Commentary, Poppins Pop Up Fun facts. Sequel: Disney's Mary Poppins Returns will be released December 25, 2018. It started production in February 2017. Starring Emily Blunt as "Mary Poppins", Lin-Manuel Miranda, Ben Whishaw, Emily Mortimer, Julie Walters, Colin Firth, Meryl Streep, and a cameo appearance by Dick van Dyke as "Mr. Dawes Jr" and Angela Lansbury as "Balloon Lady". Story set 20 years later. Julie Andrews has turned down a cameo appearance because she thought it might be distracting. She said "This is Emily's Show, I really want it to be Emily's show". Also see: Saving Mr. Banks (2013). Books: Mary Poppins: 80th Anniversary Collection.

Great Movie!

My affection for this film has unchanged from my first viewing at age 4 at Boston's Gary Theatre.  This is Walt Disney's masterwork.  One critic thought it was a pinfeather short of perfection.  I politely disagree.  It is perfection.  Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke give splendid performances, as do Glynis Johns, David Tomlinson, Ed Wynn, Karen Dotrice and Matthew Garber.  The Sherman Brothers score, expertly arranged and conducted by Irwin Kostal, is simply magical.  "Feed the Birds (Tuppence A Bag)" is hauntingly beautiful.  "Supercal . . " has an infectious, British musical hall air, while Tomlinson's "patter" songs such as "The Life I Lead" and "A British Bank" are no less skilled.  Kudos to all who had a hand with this instant classic.  This is not a "Children's Movie."  There is much to recommend to adults, too.

Disney's best film; never equaled, never duplicated, literally the best thing he ever made, his one and only masterpiece.  The music is perfect, the cast was sublime, the story..........well, with P.L. Travers as a `consultant' it's her own darn fault that she didn't pay closer attention to the contract stipulating that Disney had final say-so.  Of course it bears little resemblance to her book.  It's Disney for pity sake; the man was never faithful to any book he purloined onto film.  Even so, all the right ingredients fused into one of the best movies ever made (I'm tempted to think it was a fluke on Disney's part, since he was never able to duplicate the success or artistry of this film).

I have to say that I don't mind Dick Van Dyke's dubious accent.  He has charm to spare, it worked just fine.  I'm more concerned that poor Bert never seemed able to hold down a single job throughout the film.

Come on, it's Mary freaking Poppins. Of course it's 5 stars. I'm trying to find things I ordered that aren't 5 stars so I don't look like that jerk who gives 5 stars to everyone all the time, but Mary ain't the one who's going down. She and her carpet bag get ALL THE STARS.

Many people have fond memories of this film.  However great the VFX were in the day and how awesome the musical scores are, it is still full of filler and short on plot.  The floating uncle, for instance, adds little to any plot points and is just for fun.  At times the plot feels aimless.  It's not meant to be an involving story, but if the film were a little shorter it would have merited another star because it derails itself so many times...perhaps that's part of the fun.  Just a difference in the times we are in, that's all.  Still a cheery and fun movie for all ages.

Wonderful old story with great music and creative imagination for kids and adults.  I got it as a follow-up to the movie; "Saving Mr. Banks" and because we didn't have a good copy around for the grandkids. The basic story line is parents obsessed with their outside lives who do not take the time to love and enjoy their kids. Another nanny is hired to "handle" the children and in steps (or flies) Mary Poppins, i.e. Julie Andrews.  Dick Van Dyke has a strong supporting role as a creative chimney sweep.  Great fun, great songs (Julie Andrews at her best!) Plus a charming story line. If you don't love it --- well, decide for yourself.  I loved it.

After a few minutes in, I realized I actually never saw this film before! Apparently, because it was a Disney film and I was a high schooler at the time, I felt it had nothing for me.

Note that days before I watched this, I watched "Saving Mr. Banks", which is the story of how Walt Disney convinced PL Travers, author of MARY POPPINS, to let him make a film of her book. The interplay of that story with the fantasy, songs, animation, the incredible talents of Dick Van Dyke and Julie Andrews at the early stages of their careers (whew!!) made parts of this film poignant instead of fun.

For example, the author's father was an alcoholic banker who died of TB and was idolized by his daughter in real life, whereas the "Mary Poppins" Mr. Banks is a stuffy banker who has a comeuppance, loses his job, becomes giddy on the word "supercalifagilisticexpedali..." -- um, you know! -- a bunch of other things that might ruin it if I tell you, then the film ends with Mr. Banks repairing the children's broken kite and they go fly it, to that awful tune I can't get out of my head, "Let's go fly a kite".

If you have any doubts about whether you will like the film, watch the "Saving Mr. Banks" film first. If you just want some light fun, don't watch "Saving Mr. Banks" till after. I DO recommend you watch both close to each other, though, for a richly layered, bittersweet look at a classic Disney film.

Like many other reviewers I was motivated to re-watch Mary Poppins after enjoying Saving Mr. Banks. I have to agree with P.L. Travers--Dick Van Dyke has no place in this movie. Was he the big star at the moment? I know Julie Andrews had been passed over for My Fair Lady because she wasn't considered a proven movie star--and this was her next big break. DVD has WAAAAAY too much screen time, tedious dance and humor scenes with his annoying Cockney accent. I would edit out those scenes if I were going to watch it again. Mary/Julie's scenes are much better and the children and Banks parents were good. But a movie truer to the book (which I am also reading now for the first time), with a few musical numbers, would have been much better.

Liked: The Life I Lead (Mr. Banks), The Perfect Nanny (Jane), Spoonful of Sugar, Supercalifragilistic (OK on it's own)--that's about it, Fly a Kite (OK)

Didn't like: any of Dick VD's interminable numbers (One Man Band, Jolly Holiday/Penguins/Carousel), I love to Laugh (arrghhhhh), Chim Chim Cheree, Step in time--God---how many were there???)

Really Hated: Feed the Birds. This is a nice enough song on it's own and was used to beautiful effect in Saving Mr. Banks. Used in the original movie it was scary--like a horror flick--hundreds of pigeons crawling over a corpse of a homeless person for a LONG TIME--they really thought that would be charming to children????

Caveat on Mr Banks--the flashback scenes trying to explain PLT's damaged psyche went on and on and on. After seeing Mary Poppins I think PLT was right on in her concern.

After watching and thoroughly enjoying Saving Mr. Banks, our family decided to watch Marry Poppins again.  I grew up singing songs from this show, but even so I was starting to forget the absolute genius of this film.  Admittedly the "Jolly holiday with Mary" sequence goes on for a bit too long (they probably could have cut out either the fox hunt or the horse race) but otherwise most every scene is magical.  Dick van Dyke's performance is a tour de force and Julie Andrews is at her subtle best as the nanny who never explains anything.  Nearly every cast member could be commended for their performances, but I would be especially remiss not to mention Arthur Treacher's fine performance as the constable.  My son was able to easily pick out that Uncle Albert was played by Ed Wynn who was also portrayed the Mad Hatter in Disney's animated rendition of Alice in Wonderland.  I suggest that you cue this film up the next time you have a free evening and remind yourself all over again what a landmark piece of cinema it really was.
Ya know things just don't change. I loved it in my childhood, my children loved it and now I pass that love to my grandbabies. Its awesome.

For over 50 years, Mary Poppins has defined Disney Magic and is an excellent film.

Partly based on P.L. Travers' childhood, but more fictionalized.
A hard-working man with a suffrage wife, two domestics and two unruly children must seek help in raising his children whose nanny has quit. Originally his choice for a nanny isn't what the children have in mind. However, out of the blue comes a beautiful woman by the name of "Mary Poppins", and while she takes the children on unbelievable outings she teaches them how to behave properly, and opens their father's eyes and makes him realize love is more powerful than money.

With Five Academy Awards, catchy songs from the Sherman Brothers and outstanding performances from Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke. "Mary Poppins" is fun from start to finish, and you'll find yourself singing to the songs "Spoonful of Sugar" and "Chim Chim Che-ree".

While P.L. Travers despised the film years later, it has remained a staple in many childhoods and is a must see for anyone who is a child or a kid at heart.
Who wouldn't be happy with Walt Disney and Mary Poppins.  Mary Poppins is a movie to cherish for a lifetime.

The Chimmney sweep was in way too many sequences of the film, His dancing once was enough.

The riduluous treatment of Mrs Banks who was interested in voting rights for women were diminished by the ignorant, unmotherly treatment by Walt Disney.

If you've had a long day and need a family, feel-good movie, you can't beat Mary Poppins. Aesthetically and technically, this movie has something for everyone. Great music score, outstanding choreography, and delightful animation. Produced in 1964, all of the animations and special effects were done without computer aid. This involved detailed matte painting and frame-by-frame rotoscoping and cell animation. Never an easy task.

Grab a bowl of popcorn, sit back, and enjoy.
Classic movie - great for the entire family.  Had to watch it after Saving Mr. Banks, to get the underlying story.

This is a great fun movie. The characters are funny. Julie Andrews was fun to watch. Except for Dick Van Dyke's accent,he was great. Watched it right after watching Saving Mr Banks. So we knew the story behind it. This is also a great children's movie. The special effects are a little hokey compared with today's movies. But that's ok. We recommend it.
A happy memory movie and the special features with commentary is delightful to listen to! Buy it for yourself, buy it for the grandchild not yet born!

After seeing Saving Mr Banks, I made a point of watching Mary Poppins.  It was really wonderful to see this movie the first time and the way they used to make film. We love the story of Mary Poppins, but we're disappointed that the service kept pausing the movie to stream and load it. The last third of the viewing was great, but we had a lot of interruptions in the first 2/3rds of the movie.  The movie gets a five star, the service provider gets the one star!

I love the ability to instantly rent and view movies, but as a hearing impaired individual, the convenience is made moot by the fact that the majority of movies do not support Closed Captioning. I hope Amazon will give this some major attention soon, as I'm unlikely to use the service much until I can actually tell what the movie is saying!

My daughter and I just watched Saving Mr. Banks a few days ago, and then the same night, me and my daughter watched Mary Poppins, and this was the first time my 7 year old daughter had ever seen Mary Poppins, and she absolutely feel in love with the movie! It was really great that she watched Saving Mr. Banks first, and then watched Mary Poppins second, because Saving Mr. Banks is about the story and the making of Mary Poppins, so it really tied everything together. I would highly recommend this movie for any parent buying for their kids, and if this is the first time your children will be watching Mary Poppins, I would definitely recommend watching Saving Mr. Banks first, and then watching Mary Poppins second, because it will tie everything together and make for a remarkable movie experience for anyone adult or child alike!

The beloved Disney version of P.L. Travers' magical nanny in sparkling high definition. A must have for anyone whose delight begins at the opening credits and continues through each ensuing episode until the kites soar with the music at the finale. No need for a plot synopsis here - this wonderful fairy tale with its brief bits of dark and scary ends joyfully even as Mary Poppins flies back into the clouds, her work in the Banks household finished. The special features are of special interest as Richard Sherman (who with his brother Robert composed the lilting score) is shown collaborating and consulting with Jason Schwartzman who plays him in Saving Mr. Banks. There are scenes with Emma Thompson being seduced into giving her approval for Mary Poppins to be filmed which will make you want to see it too.
The movie is an awesome classic with catchy tunes! Great work from two of the best acors in the business, Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke.

This beloved classic Walt Disney flick shines like never before on Blu-ray with an all-new digital restoration. Winner of five Academy Awards, including Best Actress (Julie Andrews), Best Song ("Chim Chim Cher-ee") and Best Visual Effects, Mary Poppins is a movie experience your family will enjoy over and over again.

The "Practically Perfect In Every Way" Mary Poppins flies out of the windy London skies and into the home of 2 mischievous children. With the help of a carefree chimney sweep named Bert (Dick Van Dyke), the spirited British nanny turns every chore into a game and every day into a "Jolly Holiday."

Share the music, share the magic, share the joy of Mary Poppins with a whole new generation for the first time on Disney Blu-ray.
This movie received 13 Academy Award nominations and won 5 Oscars for Best Actress, Best Song, Best Music Score, Best Film Editing, and Best Special Visual Effects.

It also received a special scientific award for the creation and application of Color Traveling Matte Composite Cinematography, which helped make the combination of live action and animated actors in the film possible.

This childhood classic also takes me back to memory lane to when I was 6 going on 7 years old in the 1st grade and saw it at the movie theatre in the Summer of 1979.

It streamed flawlessly from beginning to end, and I was actually amazed at how instantly the stream started. There did not seem to be a buffer period. I am an avid Netflix watcher, which does have a (usually) brief buffering time, so this was impressive to me.

MARY POPPINS [1964/2013] [50th Anniversary Edition] [Blu-ray + DVD + Digital Copy] Walt Disneys Crowning Achievement! Celebrate The 50th Anniversary Of A Disney Classic!

Mary Poppins was released on 27th August, 1964 to universal acclaim. Released from the Walt Disney Vault in celebration of its 50th Anniversary Edition, this beloved classic shines like never before on Blu-ray with an all-new digital restoration. Mary Poppins is a film experience your family will enjoy over and over again. Practically Perfect In Every Way Mary Poppins flies out of the windy London skies and into the home of two mischievous children. With the help of a carefree chimney sweep named Bert [Dick Van Dyke], the spirited nanny turns every chore into a game and every day into a Jolly Holiday. Share the music; share the magic, share the joy of Mary Poppins with a whole new generation for the first time on Disney Blu-ray.

FILM FACT: Awards and Nominations: 1965 Academy Awards: Win: Best Actress in a Leading Role for Dame Julie Andrews. Win: Best Film Editing for Cotton Warburton. Win:  Best Visual Effects for Eustace Lycett, Hamilton Luske and Peter Ellenshaw. Win: Best Original Song "Chim Chim Cher-ee" for Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman. Win: Best Score for Richard M. Sherman, Robert B. Sherman. Nominated:  Best Picture for Walt Disney and Bill Walsh. Nominated: Best Director for Robert Stevenson. Nominated: Best Adapted Screenplay for Don DaGradi and Bill Walsh. Nominated: Best Cinematography in Color for Edward Colman. Nominated: Best Art Direction in Color for Carroll Clark, Emile Kuri, Hal Gausman and William H. Tuntke. Nominated: Best Costume Design in Color for Tony Walton. Nominated: Best Sound Mixing for Robert O. Cook. Nominated: Best Adaptation or Treatment Score for Irwin Kostal. 1965 Golden Globe Awards: Win: Best Performance by an Actress in a Leading Role in a Musical or Comedy for Dame Julie Andrews. Nominated: Best Motion Picture in a Musical or Comedy for Bill Walsh, Robert Stevenson and Walt Disney. Nominated: Best Performance by an Actor in a Leading Role in a Musical or Comedy for Dick Van Dyke. Nominated: Best Original Score for Richard M. Sherman, Robert B. Sherman. 1965 Grammy Awards: Win: Best Recording for Children for David Tomlinson, Dame Julie Andrews, Dick Van Dyke, Ed Wynn, Glynis Johns, Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman. Win: Best Original Score Written for a Motion Picture or Television Show for Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman. 1965 New York Film Critics Circle: Nominated: Best Actress for Dame Julie Andrews. 1965 Directors Guild of America Award: Nominated: Outstanding Directorial Achievement in Motion Pictures for Robert Stevenson. 1965 Writers Guild of America Award: Win: Best Written American Musical for Bill Walsh and Don DaGradi, In 2013, the film was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant." Mary Poppins is widely considered to be one of the greatest films of all time and Walt Disney's "crowning achievement". It was the only film of Disney's to garner a "Best Picture" nomination at the Oscars in his lifetime.

Andrews Blu-ray Review: Wind's in the east, mist comin' in. Like something is brewin,' about to begin. Can't put me finger on what lies in store. But I feel what's to happen, all happened before.

Adapted from a series of books by P.L. Travers, Mary Poppins was one of the last projects personally supervised by Walt Disney. Directed by Robert Stevenson, written by Bill Walsh and Don DaGradi, and with music and lyrics by Richard and Robert Sherman, this musical is a fantastical, comedic romp about a magical English Nanny who flies into a needful family's life when the wind changes.

Practically perfect in every way, Mary Poppins [Dame Julie Andrews], arrives in London to help the Banks family. Children Michael and Jane are mischievous terrors who have gone through six nannies in the last four months. Worse, they have no real relationship with their overly stuffy and strict father, Mr. Banks [David Tomlinson]. With the assistance of her chimney sweep / street artist friend, Bert [Dick Van Dyke], Mary Poppins introduces Michael and Jane to a wondrous world where laughing makes you float, where you can jump into an animated world via sidewalk art, and where chimney sweeps perform elaborate dance numbers on rooftops.

As Mary Poppins changes the world and people around her, Mr. Banks fights to stay stuck in his stuffy ways. Englishmen and bankers must be formal and precise, but Mary Poppins' silly words and infectious spirit slowly breaks down the father, allowing him to see the joys in fully engaging in the lives of his children. A classic film that combines just about every technology innovation developed at Walt Disney Studios... where should we begin our analysis today?

I don't know about you, but simply hearing the 'Mary Poppins' overture on this Blu-ray's main menu instantly makes me feel like a child again. Memories sprang up of tuning in the 'Wonderful World of Disney' on Sunday evenings during the Michael Eisner era where he, in the tradition of Mr. Walt Disney, introduced us to a catalogue of wonderful family films. As a child, these television broadcasts, combined with theatrical re-releases, made the entire Walt Disney catalogue feel new.

Looking at the film today I saw so many new details that my younger-self had never noticed or remembered. As a self-diagnosed story addict, we could have a chat about how little actually happens in the film, or how, during the animated sequences, Michael and Jane simply disappear for great swaths of time to allow Dame Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke to (rightfully) take centre stage. But you know what, our modern conventions, our development process of "rules" could never allow for such a production to be made today.

'Mary Poppins' is a deceptively simple story on purpose. Mary Poppins comes to London and changes one family's life by helping a man become a better father, right? Many family films have a variation on this age old tale. But why? Because in simplicity, in a story anyone can follow, the filmmakers jam packed this classic film with so many genre-bending sequences. Tangents, all of them, designed to slap smiles on our faces as wide as Uncle Albert's and then, at the end, to pull our heart strings when Mary Poppins departs, having succeeded, but seemingly destined to face the world alone.

Basically, 'Mary Poppins' is the perfect film to watch with your family and friends of all ages. In addition to amazing children alike and allowing you to remember your own childhood days (assuming you've been a youngster sometime in the last 50 or so years), 'Mary Poppins' boasts a wonderful sense of innocence and nostalgia that represents, to me at least, a lot of what Walt Disney created in all of his films and theme parks. Walt Disney wanted us to experience the world, if only for a short time, the way most of us only can at the beginnings of our lives. He wanted us to marvel at the wonder of it all. He wanted us to believe in silly things, to laugh and enjoy whatever moments we can without worry. Mary Poppins might not be real? But the film 'Mary Poppins' is best described as a magical experience.

We should probably also talk about what a technological marvel the film truly is. Disney's team of filmmakers assembled a project that truly wouldn't be rivalled, visually, until 'Star Wars' blew audiences' minds. Shot entirely on sound stages, 'Mary Poppins' extends its universe with gorgeous matte paintings, similar to those used in 'Citizen Kane,' and numerous instances of optical compositing. To combine live action and animation, something Disney had been doing since his first silent version of 'Alice in Wonderland' which they used the Sodium Vapour Process, aka the "yellow screen process" to create a traveling matte so actors could dance around in just about any background. It was so amazing at the time 'Mary Poppins' premiered; it went on to win an Academy Award in 1965. More than the visual effects, the animation itself is gorgeous and there are numerous practical effects with floating people and animatronic animals and that truly make one of the true technological marvels of 1960s Hollywood. By the way, watch all of the Credits to the very end, as you will hear the actual voice of P. L. Travers, who taped all the recordings and telling how the author of Mary Poppins should be portrayed on the film and P. L. Travers seems somewhat cordial during these particular excerpts from her recordings, but her rigidness can still be detected in the tone of her voice. For those two short weeks in 1961, Walt Disney pulls out all the stops. Armed with imaginative storyboards and chirpy songs from the talented Sherman Brothers, Walt Disney launches an all-out onslaught on P. L. Travers, but the prickly author doesn't budge. He soon begins to watch helplessly as P. L. Travers becomes increasingly immovable and the rights begin to move further away from Walt Disneys grasp.

'Mary Poppins,' thanks to Walt Disney's collaboration with dozens of talented writers, singers, dancers, animators, actors and crew members, is everything Walt Disney did well... all in one project. For those reasons, and many more, it's not only an excellent film to watch and enjoy as often as you please, it's also a really important film for its breakthroughs and as a crowning masterpiece just before the death of one of Hollywood's most influential storytellers and that of course was the brilliant and prolific Walt Disney.

Blu-ray Video Quality  'Mary Poppins' [50th Anniversary Edition] rides up the bannister onto Blu-ray with a resplendent 1080p encoded image, framed in the film's original 1.66:1 aspect ratio. Digitally restored for high definition, 'Mary Poppins' looks absolutely fantastic on Blu-ray. Grain levels are intact and filmic. Colour reproduction is bright, bold, and accurate and especially the fanciful cartoon sequences. Contrast is dynamic, and black levels, like the bankers' suits and hats, are decidedly dark. But none of those highlights compare to overall image resolution and detail. Human faces and other clothing textures are impressive. You'll see individual hair follicles, wrinkles, and even makeup effects on the Senior Mr. Dawes. And finally, as far as I could tell, I didn't see a tuppence worth of dirt, scratches, or other damage. For minor quibbles to discuss, this is some minor ringing around characters in a few shots, and many special effects shots and composites, including the opening title sequence, suffer noticeable resolution drops and grain spikes. Understandable, given the compositing techniques of the day, is not a big problem, overall.

Blu-ray Audio Quality  'Mary Poppins' dances and sings its way on to Blu-ray with a robust English 7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio sound mix. We have what appears to be an expanded version of the near-field mix created a decade ago. Dialogue and singing voices literally take centre stage and are always clear and vibrant. The film's score nicely films out the multichannel soundstage. And there are even a few wonderful moments, like exploding fireworks during "Step in Time," where all eight channels spring to life with active, almost-aggressive panning and thundered surround sound. In terms of "faults," it's a little quieter than some mixes, simply in terms of what levels I usually set my receiver, and the centre channel might be a little hot compared to the stereo mix. And as we would expect from similar era soundtracks, the dynamic range is a wee bit limited, but that's okay. Alternate audio tracks include 5.1 Dolby Digital mixes in English, French, or Spanish, as well as the "Original Theatrical Mix" in the 2.0 Dolby Digital Stereo mix. I can't speak, personally, to how "original" this mix is, but the stereo track is also quite good and doesn't sound noticeably compressed and it even matrixes well in Dolby Pro Logic II. Post Script: The only thing that truly bothered me about this release was Menu and Sub Menu functionality. To access various language tracks and Special Features, must one endlessly hunt for choices along horizontal lists that aren't very functional. For example, if you click past the last item, you end up at the beginning and have to click all the way through again. Further, getting back to the Main Menu itself can be a bit of a chore. Surprising in this day and age, but if anyone from Walt Disney Home Entertainment is reading this; I would personally suggest avoiding this particular menu structure in favour of something more versatile.

Blu-ray Special Features and Extras:

Special Feature: Becoming Mr. Sherman [1080p] [14:00] Goes behind-the-scenes of director John Lee Hancock's Saving Mr. Banks which stars Tom Hanks as Walt Disney and Emma Thompson as "Mary Poppins" author P. L. Travers. Actor Jason Schwartzman sits down with Mary Poppins' Richard M. Sherman to discuss the classic film's music and lyrics. Richard M. Sherman in turn shares his memories of Mary Poppins' troubled pre-production and discusses Jason Schwartzman's portrayal of him in John Lee Hancock's film.

Special Feature: Mary-Oke [1080p] [Dolby Digital Stereo] [8:00] Sing along with "A Spoonful of Sugar," "Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious," "Step in Time" and "Chim Chim Cher-ee" with this karaoke-style feature.

Classic DVD Bonus Features: The Blu-ray edition of Mary Poppins also includes most every previously released bit of supplemental content from past releases. Extras include:

Audio Commentary: Commentary with composers and lyricists Richard and Robert Sherman and actors Dame Julie Andrews [Mary Poppins], Dick Van Dyke [Bert/Mr. Dawes Sr.] and Karen Dotrice [Jane Banks] here they all reminisce about the film and its production, commenting on the challenges they faced, the fun they had and the magic they helped make. The only downside is that all five participants aren't together in the same room; Dame Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke cosy up, but Karen Dotrice and are paired up and recorded separately, while Robert B. Sherman is by his lonesome. It's only a small complaint, though. The carefully compiled track is entertaining and engaging no matter who's speaking, and Dame Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke are an absolute joy to listen to.

Special Feature: Disney on Broadway [480i] [55:00] Next up is a special documentary entitled: "Mary Poppins From Page to Stage," and here we have an overview of the film's Broadway adaptation with producer/President Disney Theatrical Productions Thomas Schumacher and performers Ashley Brown [Mary Poppins] and Gavin Lee [Bert] and a 7 minute feature, "Step in Time," with Broadway composer George Stiles.

Special Feature: Backstage Disney [480i] [113:00] Eight additional spoonfuls of supplemental sugar are also available with the following special documentaries entitled: "The Making of Mary Poppins;" vintage red carpet features "The Gala World Premiere" and "The Gala World Premiere Party;" kid-friendly special effects mini-doc "Movie Magic;" two "Deconstruction of a Scene" features "Jolly Holiday" and "Step in Time;" a "Dick Van Dyke Make-Up Test" and a "Publicity" roundup with original trailers, re-issue trailers and TV spots.

Special Feature: Music & More [1080p and 480i] [52:00] Four music-themed retrospective extras: "A Magical Musical Reunion Featuring Dame Julie Andrews, Dick Van Dyke and Richard Sherman" [489i]. Deleted song "Chimpanzoo" [480i]. "Disney Song Selection" suite [1080p] [7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio], and a "Movie Sing-Along" track.

Special Feature: Bonus Short: The Cat that Looked at a King [2004] [480i] [10:00] In this live-action/animated short, Dame Julie Andrews leads two children into a chalk drawing and tells them the story of a talking cat, a knowledge-obsessed king and the arrogant ruler's neglected queen. Contributors to this bonus short are as follows: Dame Julie Andrews, Dylan Cash, Olivia DeLaurentis, Sarah Ferguson (voice), David Ogden Stiers (voice) and Tracey Ullman (voice). Directed by Peter Schneider. Produced by  Baker Bloodworth, Gerard DiNardi and Yukari Kiso. Screenplay by Shirley Pierce (story adaptation) and P.L. Travers (book "Mary Poppins Opens the Door"). Music by Mark Watters. Cinematography by Kenneth H. Wiatrak.

Finally, without question, Walt Disney's Mary Poppins has remained a perennial firm favourite during the last half-century, thanks in large part to Dame Julie Andrews' career-defining performance and the Sherman Brothers' memorable songs. The film holds its own some fifty years past its prime, Dame Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke are fantastic and fantastically fun, the songs are treasures in and of themselves, and the age of the production has little bearing on the end result. Fortunately, Disney's Blu-ray release is deserving of the title "definitive." The film holds its own some fifty years past its prime, Dame Julie Andrews and Dick Van Dyke are fantastic and fantastically fun, the songs are treasures in and of themselves, and the age of the production has little bearing on the end result. Fortunately, Walt Disney's Blu-ray release is deserving of the title "definitive." This 50th Anniversary Blu-ray is anchored by a fantastic A/V presentation, and a generous selection of supplemental materials, there aren't any downsides or drawbacks to be found. Add Mary Poppins to your Blu-ray collection post haste, as it is an honour to have such a beautiful magical film added to my ever increasing Walt Disney Blu-ray Collection and reacquaint yourself with the magic of one of Walt Disney's most treasured classics, live-action or otherwise. Very Highly Recommended!

Andrew C. Miller  Your Ultimate No. 1 Film Fan
Le Cinema Paradiso
WARE, United Kingdom

This live action/animated musical is now celebrating its 50th Anniversary. You get a Blu-ray, DVD, and a digital copy (iTunes, Amazon, Vudu, etc.) in this release. The picture quality is terrific and the audio quality is great. Many of the special features were produced for the 40th Anniversary DVD and remain in SD (though a few are in widescreen). There are two new supplements: Becoming Mr. Sherman (14:01, HD) and Mary-Oke (7:58, HD). There is over 4 hours of total bonus content plus an audio commentary.

Video Resolution/Codec: 1080p/AVC MPEG-4 | Aspect Ratio: 1.66:1
Audio Formats: English DTS-HD Master Audio 7.1, English Dolby Digital 5.1, French Dolby Digital 5.1, Spanish Dolby Digital 5.1
Subtitles/Captions: English SDH, French, Spanish

*Music & More

Deleted Song: "Chimpanzoo" (1:38).
Disney Song Selection (32:55, HD).

*Bonus Short: 'The Cat That Looked At a King' (9:52).

*Mary-Oke (7:58, HD)

Having seen 50+ year old movies restored to better than their original glory when released onto Blu-ray, this one falls short.  The sound is good, and some color balancing is better than the 40th anniversary edition where people's faces were too gray, but the contrast and grain of this release make the picture look old and worn out.  As if the Disney company really didn't want to put in the full effort required to bring this up to snuff.  As two better examples, all you need to see is the Sound of Music (made one year later), or Rear Window (made a decade earlier), both on Blu-ray to see how significantly better those films appear than this one.  After the botched restoration efforts of those two movies in earlier DVD releases, the Blu-ray releases not only provided the added resolution and clarity that comes with blu ray, but proper digital handling of the source material brought the films up to better-than-original form (something which is now quite common -- check out the Wizard of Oz first Blu-ray release).

Alas, we have a long-anticipated Blu-ray release which looks to be just another recycled old war-horse, peddled by what is clearly now just a finance company, not willing to give more than they think they can, contrary to what Walt would have expected from them.

I think everybody with little children should have this movie in their collection.

The 2013 movie "Saving Mr. Banks" offers some insights into Walt Disney's difficult dealings with P.L. Travers, the deeply damaged and damaging, tortured and tormented author of the "Mary Poppins" books. As "Saving Mr. Banks" is a different movie, I won't go into it here. But, given Disney's prolonged difficulties with the prickly Mrs. Travers, it is a minor miracle that the movie "Mary Poppins" turned out to be an uplifting masterpiece, full of healing, hope and, yes, magic. Yes, Mrs. Travers HATED Disney and the movie. Well, Travers and her protestations be damned! The rest of the world embraced it. The 2013 Blu-Ray release looks Supercalifraglisticexalidocious, even though the Blu-Ray format and technology does reveal some of the movie-making magic tricks. But, fantasy does require a healthy, happy suspension of disbelief. And, after 50 years, "Mary Poppins" holds up remarkably well.
  Mrs. Travers' "Mary Poppins" books are a whimsical collection of quaint and magical short stories. But those hoping, possibly demanding,  for a literal adaptation are seriously deluded. The books have NO plot. Mary Poppins comes and goes arbitrarily. The screenplay by Don Degradi and Bill Walshe  gives "Poppins" a plot and a purpose. There is definitely a reason for Mary Poppins to arrive and a reason for her to leave. In between her arrival and departure, there is a profound emotional journey for audiences of all ages.
  True, there is more vinegar than sugar in Mrs. Travers' Mary Poppins. In a 1964 interview, Julie Andrews explained her approach to the character, "At first, I thought I would play Mary Poppins very stiff and exactly like the books. But that didn't seem very human... so I finally decided to mix a bit of warmth in with it." Apparently, Mrs. Travers was adverse to any suggestion of warmth whatsoever.  As portrayed by Julie Andrews, Mary maintains her aura of enigmatic mystery. She is a nanny on a mission; with a no-nonsense demeanor, crisp and efficient,  employing clever amounts of reverse psychology in her dealings with children and adults.
  Mrs. Travers did vehemently object to Disney's casting of Dick Van Dyke as Poppins' platonic pal Bert. Her objections on this point are partially valid. As an American in a British cast, Van Dyke, with an awful Cokney accent, stands out as the only "non authentic"  actor in the cast. Still, Van Dyke has excellent chemistry with Andrews, playing Bert with an appropriate sense of childlike enthusiasm and wonder. He is also excellent in the exuberant musical numbers by Robert and Richard Sherman.  Perhaps to make up for his questionable casting as Cockney Bert, versatile Van Dyke also plays Mr. Dawes, the extremely elderly Senior Officer at the bank where Mr. Banks is employed.
  Mary Poppins literally flies down into the Banks household, and just in time. The atmosphere is complete chaos since Katie Nanny (Elsa Lancaster) quit. Mrs. Banks (Glynis Johns) seems a warm and loving mother, but she is preoccupied with her political involvement with the Suffergettes. She humorously tells her maid (Hermione Baddley) after returning home from a meeting, "Ellen, put these things away. You know how the cause infuriates Mr. Banks." Mr. Banks (David Tomlinson) is harried and weary from his job at the bank. Quickly employing herself as the new nanny, Mary Poppins and her friend Bert take Jane and Michael (Karen Dotrice and Matthew Garber) on magical adventures; including a Jolly Holiday inside one of Bert's sidewalk chalk drawings, and a tea party on the ceiling with Mary's giggling Uncle Albert (Ed Wynn). Mr, Banks is infuriated to  hear  of this ridiculous nonsense. Using her trademark reverse psychology, Mary Poppins suggests that he take the children with him on a trip to the bank. This sets the events in motion that will save Mr. Banks, making him a real, emotionally connected father. Her mission accomplished, Mary Poppins flies away,  in unsentimental fashion.
  The movie was, and remains, an outstanding critical and commercial success; nominated for 13 Academy Awards; winning Best Special Effects, Best Song ("Chimm Chimm Cherrie") and Best Musical Score for Robert and Richard Sherman, and Best Actress for Julie Andrews. The only person who did not share in the success was Mrs. Travers, who never allowed herself to. Cold as ice  and emotionally damaged and  unreachable,  Mrs. Travers always hated Disney and wouldn't allow a moment of happiness to shine through her embittered heart.
  The Blu-Ray includes all The Special Features from previous DVD releases. The only section I do not like is the "Page To Stage" section; about the Broadway adaptation with Ashley Brown and Gavin Lee as Mary Poppins and Bert. Mary Poppins may also be in books and on stage. But the film remains Mary Poppins best and most magical medium; for only on film does Mary Poppins truly soar and fly into into all of our hearts.

I loved the Mary Poppins books as a child and when I read them to my children. The movie is very enjoyable, but I am still bothered by several things. The Dick Van Dyke character is too dominant and his humor too broad. The movie seems like a vehicle to promote him and his career. I always hated the animated parts. The chalk drawings were good and the beginning animation was "chalky", but then it became too-cute, patronizing animation that lacked artistic qualities. My favorite parts are still the same and adhere most closely to the mood of the book. I love the cleaning-up-the-nursery scene and the sliding up and down the bannister. She slid up without us having to have it explained to us. The laughing tea party is a delight and I can't stop laughing myself. Feed the Birds is my favorite song and touches the right note about maintaining perspective in life. All that being said, I do enjoy this movie and will buy the early books for my grandchildren and probably show them the movie.

I didn't know when I fell in love with "Mary Poppins" that a major part of my attraction to her was her willingness to fill her work children with all types of altering goodies. In that basket, Miss Poppins was a renaissance drug pusher....eager to get her little ones back in a controllable state.
"Supercalifragilistic...." is the ultimate stoned out psychobabble diddy.
Though she wasn't necessarily a seductress, I was pretty sure that if she wanted to duet on "Chim Chim Shiree" that her master would soon fall under her spell.
You see miss Mary wasn't this good ole girl. The woman was a little lazy because she was far too anxious for her work family to handle their own chores.
So now that a half century has gone by, like "The Wizard of Oz", which was also a psychedelic trip, "Mary Poppins" is like working girls in "The Wiz".
1964 was such a magical year. After the devastating tragedy of the previous November '63, we welcome The Beatles to America, by the summer, The Supremes proudly ushered in the Motown Sound and began their counterattack to the British Invasion and then by summer's en, "Mary Poppins" flew into theaters across the country as we were still asking, "Where Did Our Love Go". It was all too enchanting. By the end of 1964, we were singing "Come See About Me" and "She Loves You" to soldout theaters with "The T.A.M.I. Show", the Baby boomer generation's first entry into "Live AID"(sans the charitable aspect) gargantuan musical event introducing the masses to The Supremes, The Rolling Stones, James Brown and various Motown acts. So holiday movie going was ideal for the 12-24 year old demographic. Mary Poppins joined Paul, John, George, Ringo, Diana Flo and Mary as the most beloved figures of 1964.
The recent release of "Saving Mr. Banks" helped to refuel interest in Miss Poppins, the original pusher woman peddling her mind altering goodies to her adopted family. "Supercalifragilisticexpealodocious" became the ultimate psychobabble theme song.

One of the better comedy movies from Walt Disney.  Julie Andrews and Dick van Dyke teamed together in this laugh a second
adventure are the perfect choices.  Julie with here natural English accent  as an English nanny who seemingly, magically shows up at the Banks family doorstep, causes a never ending cascade of activities and adventures for the two Banks children.  Of course mother and father Banks, who believe their commitment in their own individual causes for the time period, end up more and more involved in Mary's influence.  Dick van Dyke, who plays a character in the movie, Bert the chimney sweeper and Mary's friend, assists with the movies grand theme, of magical activities.  The dance and comedy routines that occur in the movie with frequent regularity use Dick's comedic abilities to a full expenditure.  I don't know who were the alternate choices for Julie and Dick when the movie was being set up, but the choices having been made, I think these two were the correct choices.  Julie Andrews and Dick van Dyke own this movie.
Julie Andrews in her prime is fantastic, Acting, Singing, and role-playing. The cast is also well chosen, along with wardrobe selections to make it complete.

One of my favorite movies and every family should own a copy, but I'm still hoping for a release that has the original release's 1.75 aspect ratio. Until then, I'm hanging on to my copy of the 2000 Gold Collection DVD with the 1.85 aspect ratio. All discs released since then have a 1.66 aspect ratio which crops the image on the sides, which is particularly noticeable in certain scenes such as with the penguins and the kite flying. The 1.85 aspect ratio isn't perfect as there is some cropping on top and bottom, but to my eye it is not as disruptive as the cropping on the sides. Too bad the 50th anniversary edition is still 1.66, but maybe there'll be a Platinum Edition with 1.85? Maybe in the 60th anniversary edition?

UPDATE 01/13/2014: I did a side-by-side comparison of the 50th Edition 2013 DVD vs. the Blu-ray and there is a little less cropping of the top and bottom in the Blu-ray. So if you can't get the 2000 Gold DVD, the 2013 Blu-ray appears be better than the DVDs after 2000.

FYI, there is also an Amazon Instant Video available in HD, i.e., 16:9, so you might think, "Aha, 16:9 is 1.78! That must be better!" But sadly, no. It is the same as the 2013 DVD release further cropped and magnified to fill a 16:9 screen. In other words, the streaming version crops even more of the top and bottom than the DVD version which already crops the top, bottom, and sides.

All that said, the movie is still amazing in every edition and most will not notice nor miss the cropped edges. And I recognize some, probably the majority, even prefer cropping to fit the screen over the "black bars" on top and bottom. But for those who want to see as much of each shot as possible, hopefully this review saves them a little trouble.

We watched this as a family on New Years Eve before we will see "Saving Mr. Banks." My daughter had never seen "Mary Poppins" before. I hadn't watched it for decades. (I *loved* it when I was a kid.)

But I don't think it aged well. Many of the dance and singing numbers were about twice as long as they should have been. The chimney sweeps dancing on the roofs was exciting, but also felt like it went on *forever.*  "I Love to Laugh" is delightful, but again too long. When the children, Mary Poppins and Bert step through Bert's chalk art is at once gorgeous, but again, the sequence is waaay too long. I saw the play "Mary Poppins," a Broadway touring company, in 2012 and didn't think any of these things. In the movie they make fun of Mrs. Banks as a suffragette, in the play/ musical she is more sympathetic.  Similarly, the class distinctions are more sharp and used for laughter or poignancy more effectively in the play.

On the other hand, Julie Andrews is *wonderful* in this. She sings so sweetly! Dick Van Dyke is great, even if his accent is terrible, it's part of the fun. He seemed to be channeling Stan Laurel. The children and the other actors are great. The music and story is pure fun.

I'm glad we saw this and I'm glad we watched it together, --mostly, my daughter stopped watching after an hour or so.  It's not the movie I remember, but it's still pretty darn good!

Walt Disney Home Entertainment gives another one of their classic films the Blu-ray upgrade it so rightfully deserves with their "Mary Poppins" 50th Anniversary Edition. No one can deny the beauty of this wonderful story. I can't think of any other Disney movie more worthy of a high-definition transfer.

The Banks family is searching for a new nanny after the children scare off their last one. The ad is answered by charming and whimsical Mary Poppins (Julie Andrews). She brings the troubled family together with the help of her chimney sweeping friend Burt (Dick Van Dyke) and a cast of magical characters that inhabit different fantastic worlds.

A solid digital restoration breathes new life into "Mary Poppins" for its 50th Anniversary Edition. The colors are vibrant and the picture is crisp and clear. Some will no doubt complain that it's a little too cleaned up, but you can't please everyone. If you want the film preserved the best way it can be right now, this is a must-have.

"Mary Poppins" 50th Anniversary Edition is presented in 7.1 DTS HDMA. It's safe to say that no one has ever heard any of the wonderful songs or accompanying sound effects the way they're presented here. Every jolly tune surrounds the viewer in a cloud of joy and delight.

Bonus material for "Mary Poppins" 50th Anniversary Edition includes some fun items. Actor Jason Schwartzman interviews Composer Richard Sherman about the movie's music in the all-new "Becoming Mr. Sherman" featurette . It also contains Mary-Oke Sing-Along, "The Making of 'Mary Poppins'" featurette, a deleted song, and a musical reunion between Julie Andrews, Dick Van Dyke, and Richard Sherman.

Any fanatical Disney enthusiast needs to update their home entertainment library with the "Mary Poppins" 50th Anniversary Edition Blu-ray. Paired with some fun special features and a wonderfully restored high-definition version of the movie, this is the definitive way to re-visit or take in the classic again or for the first time. It truly is one of the defining moments in cinema history and a jewel in Disney's crown.

I was always a Mary Poppins fan as a child, but thanks to the new Saving Mr. Banks movie I've been re-obsessing myself with her. To prepare myself for a full Mary Poppins experience, I read the original books, watched Saving Mr. Banks, and finally popped in the new Blu Ray transfer of this iconic movie. Combined, the grandeur of Mary Poppins had me in tears. There is something about her, both Disney's and Travers' versions of her, that embodies imagination and seems to be both the essence of jollity and the earnestness of tragedy. Having read the books, I understand why Travers did not want her Poppins to receive the Disney treatment, but unlike her, I believe the adaptation was a brilliant work of art that added dimension to the books rather than take them away. As for the Blu Ray itself, I found the transfer to be exquisite. There's no question that the movie has never looked or sounded this fantastic on home media before. The half-animation half-live action sequences were even more magical than I remember as a child. I was afraid the added HD would reveal some of the '60s special effects, but actually they still boggle my mind even by today's standards. The soundtrack includes some of the best songs from any musical, ever. OVERALL: The story and back-story of Mary Poppins is nearly as incredible as the film itself. It's a miracle the film was ever made, but were it not for Travers' disagreeable critiques and prolonged refusal to sell the rights, there's no doubt in my mind that the movie would not have been nearly as good as it was. The improved special effects, Julie Andrews, Dick Van Dyke, the Sherman Brothers, Walt himself, who must have realized that his own death wouldn't be far off - it was a symphony of extraordinary talent that happened to come together and create one of the masterpieces of cinema. And were it not for Poppins, it is unlikely that we would have Julie Andrews in The Sound of Music. For art lovers, all this history is positively juicy. If you've seen this movie before, even if it was years ago, I definitely recommend reading the books and watching Saving Mr. Banks before re-watching, but either way, Mary Poppins is a classic and will be cherished by everyone.

Let's face it, MARY POPPINS does have its shortcomings: Dick van Dyke's execrable cockney accent, and a narrative that tends to sprawl - especially during the last two-thirds of the movie. But such comments are essentially irrelevant in a film whose songs are instantly memorable. I defy anyone not to emerge from the theater (or from the tablet) singing "Supercallifragilisticexpiallidocious" or "A Spoonful of Sugar," or "Let's Go Fly a Kite." I defy anyone not to have a lump in the throat as Julie Andrews sings "Feed the Birds," or to enjoy the sheer brio of the sequence celebrating "It's a Jolly Holiday with Mary." Julie Andrews is quite simply breathtaking; one understands from her performance just how good she must have been as the original Eliza Dolittle in MY FAIR LADY (and how mistaken Jack Warner was in casting Audrey Hepburn in the film version). Van Dyke gives a jaunty performance, while David Tomlinson steals the show as Mr. Banks, the bank official who learns there is is much more to life than simply earning money. The film is the kind of thing that can be watched again and again - which is why it is endlessly repeated (and revived in cinemas as a companion-piece to SAVING MR. BANKS).

I was at an age that was much too cool to ever see this movie before.  Well, that's not true either.  After having children, we did own a VHS copy that is now long gone.  Sure I've seen it with the kids but frankly wasn't paying much attention.  Now as a grizzled old grandfather, I decided to watch it the right way.  Undistracted and in high definition.

Mary Poppins, for the uninitiated, is a magical nanny created by P. L. Travers in a series of books.  This film featured Julie Andrews in her big screen debut and I must say, she is drop dead gorgeous in spite of some heavy costuming replicating 1910 London.  She is perfect as Mary Poppins, who while generally cheerful is a bit more focused on discipline than what is on the surface.  And in quiet moments seems to have unexplained feelings of remorse or regret.  Dick Van Dyke plays Bert, a street performer and some-time chimney sweep.  He not only provides a convincing fun-loving character but also shows considerable dancing ability.  This is especially evident in his dancing sequence with the controversial animated penguins.  Mrs. Travers wanted no animation in the film.

Bert and Mary know each other well and cavort about with the children on a regular basis but there is no hint of romance (another Travers stipulation).  Mary Poppins has answered an ad for a nanny that was scripted by Jane (Karen Dotrice) and Michael (Matthew Garber), the young children of Mr. and Mrs. Banks (David Tomlinson and Glynis Johns).  Mr. Banks is a bank officer and Mrs. Banks, doesn't do much of anything but attend women's suffragette meetings.  Mr. Banks is of the strict upper crust method of socializing.  He also believes children are to be seen (if they must) and certainly not heard.  He has not been happy with their lackadaisical upbringing and fired the previous nanny (Elsa Lanchester).

"Mary Poppins" is full of bright and sometimes thoughtful music throughout.  Some of the scenes are a bit lengthy as is the whole movie.  The integration of the animation with the live action is very good and revolutionary for the time.  The dance sequence involving the dozen or so chimney sweeps is beautifully choreographed.  To be sure, "Mary Poppins" is a film aimed at children and their parents.  And it is a good one.

I'm sure Hollywood will remake this movie sometime in the near future, but in my opinion you haven't seen Mary Poppins if you haven't seen the original.

This copy has been digital remastered and restored with some fun bonus content.  It is a classic movie that is timeless and one that every generation can appreciate.  I didn't think the movie could get better until I saw it on Blu-ray, granted the last version I watched was on VHS!

This was the first film Julie Andrews made after being a star on Broadway, first in My Fair Lady and then Camelot. Dick Van Dyke was already popular for his sit-com. There was chemistry between the two stars. The supporting cast of Glynis Johns, David Tomilson as well as character actor, Ed Wynn and Reta Shaw and Hermionne Badley as the servants supported them well. When I was a child, I loved the film and still love it. My favorite scenes happened when Mary, Bert and the children when they went through Bert's chalk drawing to the fair and included the songs, Jolly Holliday and Supercalifragilistic.
Purchased as a present and the quality is superb.  My daughter will get hours of enjoyment by reviewing this movie time and again.

"Chitty Chitty Bang Bang" is 1000 times more enjoyable and a better movie than "Mary Poppins. " What an inane movie!.

From the very beginning their is no rhyme or reason to this so-called story.  Even "Alice in Wonderland" makes more sense than this musical nonsense.

A  man with a medium position in a bank has 2 housekeepers and needs a nanny to take care of his 2 children when he has a wife?  If this marriage needs that many servants for 2 children with a housewife present they should never have had children.

The man is portrayed as arrogant and effeminate and the wife as a whimsical butterfly caring only about herself and her interests.  In this case, for the cause of the suffragettes.  Instead of being a mother and a teacher to her children she focuses all her attention at gallivanting in the world of men;  hence, the nanny.

After watching, with difficulty, this long and drawn out movie I could not understand how Julie Andrews won an Oscar for her role in this movie.  If she deserved an Oscar it should have been for her splendid role in  "The Sound of Music" and not for  this whirlwind of stupidity.

A nanny for 2 children who are really no trouble at all?  They have mildly untidy rooms and chase their runaway kite and they need an insane sorceress to sing them into other worlds while avoiding reality.  This domineering nanny walks in and tells the man what to do and is probably why she won the Oscar.  This film has a very blatant message and it's about women's rights.  And that it is paramount that the mother be excused from her responsibility in raising her children and that protesting and fighting against men is her true duty.

It's Feminism at its worse.  This movie in a nutshell is about Feminism disguised as a ridiculous children's tale.  It has a patriarchal nanny in charge with a weak unmanful father and a willow 'o' wisp for a mother.  This nanny evokes no warmth, tenderness or kindness but is more in line with a tolerant drill sergeant that sings cadence and smiles a lot in order to deceive.

I didn't feel any kind of sadness or joy or humor throughout the movie.  It was too  badly written, directed, and casting was questionable.  Dick Van Dyke made the movie a little bearable during his dance routine on the rooftops but that was it.

And the moral of the story is: escape reality into worlds of fantasies and let the nanny be in charge and everything will turn out alright in the end just like in the movie when the father gets canned and goes about singing  like a blithering idiot: supercalifragulisticexpialidotious.

When you ponder it, the movie teaches a lie.
It turns the home upside down.  The father is incapable of manly character and the wife is out in the streets pursuing them and the state, represented by the nanny, has to step in  with insanity to mend the torn garment.

In "Chitty Chitty Bang Bang" the man needed a wife and the children needed a mother.  He also needed a job.  He was doing the manly thing and she the womanly thing.  It was natural and it flowed.  That is a great movie.

Mary Poppins is a tale of travesty and anyone with a quarter of a brain will see through it.  I can understand 1 or 2 year old enjoying it but adults?  And, this was my first time seeing this movie that is so  well spoken of.  As always,  it's better to watch it or read it yourself than to believe what others think or say.  So be my guest and please watch it and then decide.

As a kid I remember hearing the music and I enjoyed it but the movie is a totally different  on the mind.

If you must, buy the soundtrack and enjoy the tunes but forget acquiring any moral lesson from the sad and henpecking script.  There's no moral lesson--only an immoral lesson depicting parents abandoning their duties while others step in to divert them into false dreamy paths hidden by animations, music and magic.

P.S.  Disney has stopped adding digital copies for PC Windows and instead is herding people to iTunes and others I don't use or care for.  Other companies still support Window PCs.  And if you type in the code and don't download the movie, it's still considered downloaded; hence, you end up with no digital copy.

FIRST an important note: Amazon has a policy of grouping ALL reviews of ALL formats of a film together. This means that reviews posted five years ago are grouped in the 800+ reviews on now for this title. I always recommend that, when reading Amazon reviews, you 1) look at the product that the reviewer is commenting on (its listed) and also the date of the review. (You can sort by newest first. With that said, on to my review of the 50th Anniversary RESTORED Blu-ray Combo.

Disney repackagings its classic films about every 10 years for their Anniversary Editions.  They usually add a new special feature or two and repeat the ones from prior editions. For the first Blu-ray release of MP they went the extra step and digitally remastered the film. They did an amazing job on it and, even on a basic HD flat screen TV  the images are super sharp and the colors brilliant.

There were two reasons to release this Special Edition now (three, if you consider that its Christmas gift time). One is the 50th anniversary of the films release (which is stretching it a bit since the 50th won't come until next year (2014). The other is the December 2013 release of the Disney feature film Saving Mr. Banks about the making of MP. And, trust me, Disney did not miss this opportunity to cross-market both films. The Exciting New Content on this 2013 package includes Becoming Mr. Sherman an new 11-minute featurette with actor Jason Schwartzman (who plays composer Richard Sherman in SMB) chatting with the real Richard Sherman. I can already see this being a bonus on the SMB DVD when it is released in 2014. This is followed by the 2 1/2 minute trailer for SMB. The other Exciting New Content is the Mary-oke which shows the animated lyrics to four songs on the screen so you can sing along.

All the other bonues (and there are many) are carried over from prior editions and titled Classic Bonuses. These include a 48 minute feature on bringing MP to Broadway (with the full 7-minute production number of Step In Time), a 50-minute Making of the film featurette, A 9-minute Pl> Travers story told by Julie Andrews and a full length commentary with Andrews, Dick Van Dyke and Richard Sherman. Considering that the film runs 2  hours, this means that there is over SEVEN-HOURS (!) of entertainment on this BD.

You may already own a copy of the earlier edition and not need the Classic Bonuses again. And the Becoming Mr. Sherman bonus is really an infomercial for SMB (which Im looking forward to seeing next week), but if you have a Bluray player, I feel its worth upgrading to this new edition, if only to enjoy the new crisp images from the latest restoration. (Then give your older edition to someone who has yet to experience the magic of this film.)
Ill end by saying that the film is not just for children. There are moments of humor that only an adult will notice and  until I watched it again yesterday  I didn't realize how little dialogue there is in the film; its mostly songs and production numbers! This film is not only timeless, but ageless too.

I hope you found this review both informative and helpful!

Steve Ramm
